facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 116 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 116 of 1958. Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 28,1957, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1158 of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated June 26, 1956, of the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, in G. R. Case No. 284 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 28, 1957, of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1158 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 28,1957, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1158 of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated June 26, 1956, of the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, in G. R. Case No. 284 of 1956. R. Chaudhury, for the appellant.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court judgment arose out of judgment and order dated June 26, 1956, of Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, in G.R. Case No. 284 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated June 26, 1956, of the Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta, in G. R. Case No. 284 of 1956. R. Chaudhury, for the appellant. Sen, P. K. Ghose for P. IC Bose, for the respondent. 1960. March 1 1.

facts.text: Case instituted on a police report charging appellant with offence under s.332 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The case against the appellant was instituted on a police report which charged him with an offence under s. 332 of the P.C. for voluntarily causing hurt by means of a piece of wood to the companyplainant, Sisir Kumar Bose, Bailiff of Calcutta Corporation and Chandra Sekhar Bhattacharjee, an employee of Calcutta Corporation with the intent to prevent or deter those persons from discharging their duties as public servants.

facts.text: Appellant charged with voluntarily causing hurt by piece of wood to Sisir Kumar Bose, Bailiff of Calcutta Corporation, and Chandra Sekhar Bhattacharjee, employee of Calcutta Corporation, to prevent them from discharging duties as public servants.

anchor.surface_text: which charged him with an offence under s. 332 of the P.C. for voluntarily causing hurt by means of a piece of wood to the companyplainant, Sisir Kumar Bose, Bailiff of Calcutta Corporation and Chandra Sekhar Bhattacharjee, an employee of Calcutta Corporation with the intent to prevent or deter those persons from discharging their duties as public servants. The Magistrate after satisfying himself that the documents referred to in s. 173 Cr. P. C. had been furnished to the accused examined the documents and was of opinion after hearing companynsel of both parties that the charge under s. 332 I.P.C. companyld number be sustained.

facts.text: Magistrate examined documents under s.173 CrPC, furnished to accused, heard counsel, opined charge under s.332 IPC not sustainable.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate after satisfying himself that the documents referred to in s. 173 Cr. P. C. had been furnished to the accused examined the documents and was of opinion after hearing companynsel of both parties that the charge under s. 332 I.P.C. companyld number be sustained. He was however of opinion that there was evidence to establish a prima facie case under s. 323 I.P.C.

facts.text: Magistrate opined prima facie case under s.323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He was however of opinion that there was evidence to establish a prima facie case under s. 323 I.P.C. He accordingly charged the accused under s. 323 I.P.C. examined him and when he pleaded number guilty and claimed to be tried posted the case for the examination of prosecution witnesses.

facts.text: Magistrate framed charge under s.323 IPC against accused.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly charged the accused under s. 323 I.P.C. examined him and when he pleaded number guilty and claimed to be tried posted the case for the examination of prosecution witnesses. On the next hearing date a submission was made on behalf of the accused that in view of the provisions of s. 251 2  Cr. P. C. the accused should have been acquitted altogether and numbertrial for the offence under s. 323 I.P.C. companyld be proceeded with.

facts.text: Accused pleaded not guilty to s.323 charge and claimed trial.

anchor.surface_text: examined him and when he pleaded number guilty and claimed to be tried posted the case for the examination of prosecution witnesses. On the next hearing date a submission was made on behalf of the accused that in view of the provisions of s. 251 2  Cr. P. C. the accused should have been acquitted altogether and numbertrial for the offence under s. 323 I.P.C. companyld be proceeded with.

facts.text: On next hearing, submission by accused that he should be acquitted under s.251(2) CrPC, no trial for s.323.

anchor.surface_text: On the next hearing date a submission was made on behalf of the accused that in view of the provisions of s. 251 2  Cr. P. C. the accused should have been acquitted altogether and numbertrial for the offence under s. 323 I.P.C. companyld be proceeded with. The Magistrate rejected this companytention and directed that the trial of the accused for an offence under s. 323 I.P.C. would proceed under Chapter XX.

facts.text: Magistrate rejected accused's submission and directed trial under Chapter XX for s.323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate rejected this companytention and directed that the trial of the accused for an offence under s. 323 I.P.C. would proceed under Chapter XX. That procedure was followed and ultimately the accused was companyvicted under s. 323 I.P.C. and sentenced to pay a fine of rupees fifty only and in default to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: Accused convicted under s.323 IPC and sentenced to fine of Rs.50 or one month rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: That procedure was followed and ultimately the accused was companyvicted under s. 323 I.P.C. and sentenced to pay a fine of rupees fifty only and in default to undergo rigorous imprisonment for one month. The appellants application under s. 439 Cr. P.C. for revision of this order was rejected by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant's revision application under s.439 CrPC rejected by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants application under s. 439 Cr. P.C. for revision of this order was rejected by the High Court. The learned Judge was of opinion that if the Magistrate finds on the materials before him that a summons case offence has been companymitted by the accused, he has, the right and duty to proceed in accordance with the provisions of Chapter XX of the Cr. P.C.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is filed on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution. The relevant provisions of ss. 251 and 251A of the Code of Criminal Procedure are in these words S. 251 -In the trial of warrant-cases by Magistrates, the Magistrates shall-  a in any case instituted on a police-report, follow the procedure specified in s. 251A and  b in any other case, follow the procedure specified in the other provisions of this Chapter.

facts.text: Police report facts constituted offence under s.332 IPC and also minor offence under s.323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the police report stated facts which companystituted an offence under s. 332 I.P.C. but these facts necessarily companysti. tute also a minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C. The Magistrate when he took companynizance under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C. of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. cannot but have taken companynizance also of the minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C.

facts.text: Magistrate took cognizance under s.190(1)(b) CrPC of offence under s.332 IPC and necessarily also s.323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate when he took companynizance under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C. of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. cannot but have taken companynizance also of the minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C. Consequently, even after the order of discharge was made in respect of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. the minor offence under s. 323 of which he had also taken companynizance remained for trial as there was numberindication to the companytrary.

facts.text: Magistrate made order of discharge under s.251A(2) CrPC in respect of s.332 IPC charge.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate after satisfying himself that the documents referred to in s. 173 Cr. P. C. had been furnished to the accused examined the documents and was of opinion after hearing companynsel of both parties that the charge under s. 332 I.P.C. companyld number be sustained.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by DAS GUPTA, J. on March 11, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March 1 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-The question raised in this appeal is whether a Magistrate after making an order of discharge under s. 251A 2 , Cr. P. C., in respect of a charge for an offence triable as a warrant case can still proceed to try the accused for another offence disclosed by the police report and triable as a summons case.

facts.text: Counsel: R. Chaudhury for appellant; Sen, P.K. Ghose, P. IC Bose for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: R. Chaudhury, for the appellant. Sen, P. K. Ghose for P. IC Bose, for the respondent. 1960. March 1 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-The question raised in this appeal is whether a Magistrate after making an order of discharge under s. 251A 2 , Cr. P. C., in respect of a charge for an offence triable as a warrant case can still proceed to try the accused for another offence disclosed by the police report and triable as a summons case.

issues.text: The question raised in this appeal is whether a Magistrate after making an order of discharge under s. 251A 2 , Cr. P. C., in respect of a charge for an offence triable as a warrant case can still proceed to try the accused for another offence disclosed by the police report and triable as a summons case.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised in this appeal is whether a Magistrate after making an order of discharge under s. 251A 2 , Cr. P. C., in respect of a charge for an offence triable as a warrant case can still proceed to try the accused for another offence disclosed by the police report and triable as a summons case.

issues.text: The real question is, when an order of discharge is made by the Magistrate in exercise of the powers under sub-s.  2  of s. 251A is the discharge in respect of all the offences which the facts mentioned in the police report would make out ?

arguments.court_reasoning: When Magistrate takes cognizance under s.190(1)(b) CrPC of offences on police report, it covers all offences constituted by the facts reported, not just specified ones; includes minor offence like s.323 when facts constitute s.332.

arguments.claim: If Magistrate finds summons case offence committed on materials, he has right and duty to proceed under Chapter XX CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge was of opinion that if the Magistrate finds on the materials before him that a summons case offence has been companymitted by the accused, he has, the right and duty to proceed in accordance with the provisions of Chapter XX of the Cr. P.C.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees discharge under s.251A(2) specific to warrant offence; summons offences remain triable.

arguments.claim: Discharge under s.251A(2) CrPC refers only to specific offence charged (warrant case); does not bar proceeding against other offence like summons case under Chapter XX.

anchor.surface_text: The word discharge used in sub-s.  2  of s. 251A Cr. P.C. must be read as having reference to a discharge in relation to the specific offence upon which the accused has been charge-sheeted. It does number necessarily mean that the accused cannot be proceeded against for some other. offence, say a summons case offence, under Chapter XX Cr. C. in spite of the discharge under s. 251A 2 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: presumption that the accused has companymitted an offence punishable under Chapter XXI Which the Magistrate is companypetent to try and which company

arguments.court_reasoning: Order of discharge under s.251A(2) only for offences triable under Chapter XXI; police report contains summons offences too.

arguments.claim: Order of discharge under s.251A(2) is only in respect of offences triable as warrant cases under Chapter XXI; not for all offences facts might constitute.

anchor.surface_text: The real question is, when an order of discharge is made by the Magistrate in exercise of the powers under sub-s.  2  of s. 251A is the discharge in respect of all the offences which the facts mentioned in the police report would make out ? The answer must be in the negative.

arguments.claim: When Magistrate takes cognizance under s.190(1)(b) CrPC on police report, he takes cognizance of ALL offences constituted by the facts reported, not only the named ones.

anchor.surface_text: This argument ignores the fact that when a Magistrate takes companynizance of offences under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C., he takes companynizance of all offences companystituted by the facts reported by the police officer and number only of some of such offences.

arguments.claim: Facts in police report constituted offence under s.332 IPC and necessarily also minor offence under s.323 IPC; cognizance taken of both.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the police report stated facts which companystituted an offence under s. 332 I.P.C. but these facts necessarily companysti. tute also a minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C. The Magistrate when he took companynizance under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C. of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. cannot but have taken companynizance also of the minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C.

arguments.claim: After discharge under s.251A(2) for s.332 IPC, minor offence s.323 remains for trial under Chapter XX as no indication to contrary.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, even after the order of discharge was made in respect of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. the minor offence under s. 323 of which he had also taken companynizance remained for trial as there was numberindication to the companytrary. That being an offence triable under Chapter XX Cr. C.P. the Magistrate rightly followed the procedure under Chapter XX.

arguments.claim: Under s.251A, Magistrate forms opinion on ground for presuming offence under Chapter XXI; discharge only if no such ground for those offences.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that, in deciding whether action shall be taken by him under sub-s.  2  or sub-s.  3  of s. 251A the Magistrate has to form an opinion whether there is any ground for presuming that an accused has companymitted an offence triable under Chapter XXI or there is numbersuch ground.

holdings.text: When an order of discharge is made by the Magistrate in exercise of the powers under sub-s. 2 of s. 251A, the discharge is not in respect of all the offences which the facts mentioned in the police report would make out.

anchor.surface_text: The real question is, when an order of discharge is made by the Magistrate in exercise of the powers under sub-s.  2  of s. 251A is the discharge in respect of all the offences which the facts mentioned in the police report would make out ? The answer must be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate forms opinion only on whether ground for presuming offence triable under Chapter XXI; discharge limited to those specific offences.

holdings.text: The order of discharge under s. 251A(2) has reference only to offences triable under Chapter XXI mentioned in the charge-sheet and does not affect offences triable under Chapter XX contained in the same police report.

anchor.surface_text: When the Magistrate makes an order under s. 251A 2  he does so as, after having considered whether the charge made in the police report of the offences triable under Chapter XXI is groundless he is of opinion that the charge in respect of such offence is groundless but the order of discharge has reference only to such offences mentioned in the charge-sheet as are triable under Chapter XXI.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police report often contains both warrant and summons offences; discharge specific to warrant cases under Chapter XXI.

holdings.text: When a Magistrate takes cognizance of offences under s. 190(1)(b) Cr. P.C. on a police report, he takes cognizance of all offences constituted by the facts reported by the police officer and not only of some of such offences.

anchor.surface_text: This argument ignores the fact that when a Magistrate takes cognizance of offences under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C., he takes cognizance of all offences constituted by the facts reported by the police officer and not only of some of such offences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cognizance based on facts in report encompasses all constituent offences, illustrated by examples like ss. 379 and 426 IPC.

holdings.text: In deciding under sub-s. 2 or 3 of s. 251A, the Magistrate forms opinion only on ground for presuming offence triable under Chapter XXI; discharges if no such ground for those offences.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that, in deciding whether action shall be taken by him under sub-s.  2  or sub-s.  3  of s. 251A the Magistrate has to form an opinion whether there is any ground for presuming that an accused has committed an offence triable under Chapter XXI or there is no such ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language limits inquiry to offences triable under Chapter XXI (warrant cases).

holdings.text: Facts constituting s. 332 IPC offence necessarily constitute minor offence under s. 323 IPC; cognizance of s. 332 implies cognizance of s. 323; after discharge for s. 332, s. 323 remains triable under Chapter XX.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the police report stated facts which constituted an offence under s. 332 I.P.C. but these facts necessarily consti. tute also a minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C. The Magistrate when he took cognizance under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C. of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. cannot but have taken cognizance also of the minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of general cognizance rule to facts; no contrary indication in discharge order.

holdings.text: The Magistrate rightly followed the procedure under Chapter XX for trial of the offence under s. 323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, even after the order of discharge was made in respect of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. the minor offence under s. 323 of which he had also taken cognizance remained for trial as there was no indication to the contrary. That being an offence triable under Chapter XX Cr. C.P. the Magistrate rightly followed the procedure under Chapter XX.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cognizance taken, discharge limited, summons procedure appropriate.

outcome.relief_summary: Magistrate's discharge under s.332 IPC does not bar trial for s.323 IPC under summons procedure; conviction and procedure upheld

anchor.surface_text: This argument ignores the fact that when a Magistrate takes cognizance of offences under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C., he takes cognizance of all offences constituted by the facts reported by the police officer and not only of some of such offences.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the police report stated facts which constituted an offence under s. 332 I.P.C. but these facts necessarily consti. tute also a minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C. The Magistrate when he took cognizance under s. 190 1  b  Cr. P.C. of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. cannot but have taken cognizance also of the minor offence under s. 323 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, even after the order of discharge was made in respect of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. the minor offence under s. 323 of which he had also taken cognizance remained for trial as there was no indication to the contrary. Consequently, even after the order of discharge was made in respect of the offence under s. 332 I.P.C. the minor offence under s. 323 of which he had also taken cognizance remained for trial as there was no indication to the contrary. That being an offence triable under Chapter XX Cr. C.P. the Magistrate rightly followed the procedure under Chapter XX.
